comments:
After following the instructions in the PTP MPI help for setup and run of the
test MPI program, MPI analysis fails with the following output:

 18
org.eclipse.ptp.mpi.core.actions.RunAnalyseBase.doArtifactAnalysis(RunAnalyseBase.java:597)
     19
org.eclipse.ptp.mpi.core.actions.RunAnalyseBase$AnalyseWithProgress.run(RunAnalyseBase.java:555)
     20
org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run(ModalContext.java:113)
ScanReturn result is NULL.  No results for testMPI.c

Info from Shirley, after I contacted her via email:
Beth,

Yes, I have Eclipse 3.1.1 and CDT 3.0.0.  I followed the instructions 
in the PTP MPI help for configuring the include and library files 
and checking that the indexer was turned on three times and got exactly 
the same result every time -- i.e., that the MPI analysis failed. 
Please let me know anything else you want me to try.

Here is some info about my environment:

rib{/home/shirley/eclipse}% uname -a
Linux rib 2.6.9-22.ELsmp #1 SMP Mon Sep 19 18:32:14 EDT 2005 i686 i686 
i386 GNU/Linux

Here's the command I use to start eclipse:
rib{/home/shirley/eclipse}% eclipse -vm /sw/rib/lib/jdk/jre/bin/java 
-vmargs -Xmx256M

rib{/home/shirley/eclipse}% java -version
java version "1.5.0_02"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_02-b09)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_02-b09, mixed mode, sharing)

Thanks for looking into this,
Shirley

Shirley, can you confirm that you can compile a trivial C program at least on
eclipse and CDT?

One possible failure scenario is the dialect of the file (C/C++)
Shirley, what's the file name of the file you're running the
MPI analysis on?  Is it testMPI.c?

OK, after getting more output from Shirley,
I see she's getting an UnsatisfiedLinkError before the MPI tools even run.

java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: no spawner in java.library.path
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary(ClassLoader.java:1682)
	at java.lang.Runtime.loadLibrary0(Runtime.java:822)
	at java.lang.System.loadLibrary(System.java:992)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.utils.spawner.ProcessFactory.<init>(ProcessFactory.java:35)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.utils.spawner.ProcessFactory.getFactory(ProcessFactory.java:47)
	at
org.eclipse.cdt.utils.spawner.EnvironmentReader.getEnvVars(EnvironmentReader.java:52)

Craig reported same error late last year in newsgroup:
http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.platform/msg33877.html
Will see what he found out.

(Shirley *IS* running basic test file testMPI.c, to answer previous question.
She *can* compile a basic C++ hello world program, and
Also she's on Java 5.0.  Need to document what version of Linux.)

Version info:

Shirley says.. 
We are running
[linux] cat /etc/redhat-release
Red Hat Enterprise Linux AS release 4 (Nahant Update 2)

We (IBM - Justin) can successfully run the MPI tools on a  Linux desktop (c4eb
redhat kernel 2.4).  Using gcc compiler.

To follow up on this "bug," Shirley did not have the right binary parts of CDT for her platform (Linux).

Shirley said (on 11/21/05):
>I think I can figure it out on my own, now that I have downloaded the 
>right version of CDT.  I will try it and let you know how it goes.

>The reason I had downloaded the wrong version is 
>that the only version available from the www.eclipse.org/ptp is the file 
>org.eclipse.cdt-make-1.0.0-RC1.tar.gz, 
>which doesn't indicate anywhere that it is the macosx version.  You 
>might want to change that.

Shirley, did you finally get CDT (and PTP and MPI tools) working on your system?
Beth, is this still a bug?
I believe getting the correct binaries fixed Shirley's problem.
